Gas phase hydrogenation of dimethyl-1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylate over highly dispersed and stable supported copper-based catalysts Qi Hu Guoli Fan Shaoyan Zhang Lan Yang Feng Li ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, P.O. BOX 98, Beijing 100029, PR China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology P.O. BOX 98 Beijing 100029 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 10 64451226; fax: +86 10 64425385. Graphical abstract Highly dispersed and stable supported copper-based catalysts for gas-phase hydrogenation of dimethyl 1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylate (DMCD) to 1,4-cyclohexane dimethanol (CHDM) were synthesized from a single-source Cu–Zn–Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursor. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2 sorption, H2-N2O titration and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques. The results revealed that calcination temperature for LDH precursors significantly affected the composition, structure, chemical states, and catalytic performance of copper-based catalysts. In the gas-phase selective hydrogenation of DMCD, a high CHDM yield of 95.6% was achieved over copper-based catalyst obtained at calcination temperature of 600°C. Compared with the conventional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and Cr2O3 promoted copper-based catalysts, LDH-derived Cu-based catalysts exhibited higher catalytic performance, which was mainly attributed to the presence of highly dispersed and stable active metallic copper species, as well as a reasonable amount of Cu+ species facilitating the activation of ester groups of reactants. Keywords Copper-based catalyst High dispersion Stability Dimethyl-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate Hydrogenation 1 Introduction In the past decade, 1,4-cyclohexane dimethanol (CHDM), as a chemical intermediate, has been preferred over ethylene glycol as a stepping-stone in the production of polyester fibers having excellent thermal resistance, weather resistance, and physical strength [1]. To date, on an industrial scale, the only reported feasible route to CHDM is the catalytic hydrogenation of dimethyl-1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylate (DMCD) by using Cr2O3 promoted copper-based (Cu-Cr2O3) heterogeneous catalysts [2,3]. The toxicity of such type of Cr-containing catalysts, however, causes a severe environmental pollution, in spite of the high yield of desired product. Therefore, it has always been a challenge to develop green Cr-free catalysts with high activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of DMCD [4]. In addition, supported copper-based catalysts are of great importance due to good catalytic properties in a wide range of reactions including dehydrogenations [5] and hydrogenations [6,7]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs, [M1−x 2+M x 3+(OH)2] x+[A x/n ] n−·mH2O) are known as a family of highly ordered two-dimensional hydrotalcite-like anionic clay materials [8]. Different M2+ and M3+ metal cations can uniformly distribute and orderly prearrange in the brucite-like MII 1−x MIII x (OH)2-layers. Upon calcination at intermediate temperatures (450–600°C), LDHs undergo decomposition and structural transformation, thus giving poorly crystallized mixed metal oxides with large specific surface areas, high thermal and chemical stability and homogeneous dispersion of metal components [9,10]. Correspondingly, supported metal nanocatalysts with high metal dispersion and tunable metal particle size can be obtained by reducing calcined LDHs in a controllable manner [11,12], and further applied extensively in various metal-catalyzed reactions [13–18]. For example, considerable attempts have been made to use Cu-containing LDHs as catalyst precursors for a variety of industrially important reactions including methanol steam reforming, methane synthesis, and so on [19–23]. More recently, our group reported preliminarily copper-based catalysts derived from LDH precursors containing Cu, Mg and Al, which exhibited good catalytic performance in the gas phase hydrogenation of DMCD [24]. In the present work, highly dispersed and stable supported copper-based catalysts for the gas-phase hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM were synthesized from a single-source CuZnAl-LDH precursor. Our objectives consisted in studying: (i) the feasibility of synthesis for copper-based catalysts, (iii) the influence of the calcination temperature on the composition, structure, chemical states and catalytic performance of copper-based catalysts in order to understand deeply the relationship between the structures of catalysts and their catalytic properties, and (iii) the potential of CuZnAl-LDH precursor to generate improved metal dispersion and long-term stability of catalysts in the gas-phase hydrogenation of DMCD. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts CuZnAl-LDH precursor was prepared by our previously reported separate nucleation and aging step method [25]. Solution A: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O salts with the Cu2+/Zn2+/Al3+ molar ratio of 1:1:1 were dissolved in 100mL of deionized water to give a solution with a total cationic concentration of 1.2M. Solution B: NaOH and Na2CO3 were dissolved in 100mL of deionized water to form a mixed base solution. The concentration of the base was related to those of metal ions in solution A as follows: [CO3 2−]=2[Al3+], [OH−]=1.6([M2+]+[Al3+]). Solutions A and B were added rapidly into a colloid mill with the rotor speed set at 3000rpm and mixed for 2min. The resulting blue suspension was washed several times with deionized water until pH=7, aged at 60°C for 12h, and finally dried at 70°C for 24h. The CuZnAl-LDH was calcined in static air at 400, 500, 600 and 700°C for 3h, pelletized, crushed, sieved to 40–60 mesh, and denoted as C-400, C-500, C-600 and C-700, respectively. Before the hydrogenation reaction, the calcined samples were in situ reduced in 10% H2/N2 atmosphere at 300°C for 2h at a ramp rate of 2°Cmin−1, and the obtained reduced catalysts were denoted as R-400, R-500, R-600 and R-700, respectively. For comparison, Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst with the Cu/Zn/Al molar ratio of 1/1/1 and the copper content of about 32.0wt.% was prepared through a typical co-precipitation, followed by calcination at 600°C for 3h and reduction under the same procedure as that for C-600 sample [26,27]. Another traditional Cu-Cr2O3 comparison catalyst with the Cu/Cr molar ratio of 1.0 was prepared according to the literature [28]. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected at room temperature on Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer with graphite-filtered Cu Kα source (λ =0.15418nm). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were carried out on a JEOL 2100 operated at an accelerating voltage of 200kV. Elemental mapping was performed using a HITACHI S-5500 scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) equipped with an Oxford INCA-450 Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) detector. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of samples were obtained on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 sorptometer apparatus. The total specific surface areas were evaluated with the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The mesopore size distribution and average pore diameter were determined by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on a Thermo VG ESCALAB250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer at a base pressure of 2×10−9 Pa using Al Kα X-ray radiation (1486.6eV photons). Binding energies were calibrated based on the graphite C 1s peak at 284.6eV. The reduction behavior of calcined samples was studied by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) using Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 instrument. 0.1g of sample, which was placed in a quartz U-tube reactor, was degassed at 200°C for 2h under argon flow (40mL/min). Then TPR was conducted in a stream of 10% (v/v) H2/Ar (40mL/min) with a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1 up to 800°C. The effluent gas was analyzed by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The metallic copper surface areas and metal dispersions for samples were determined according to H2-N2O titration [29–31]. First, calcined sample (100mg) underwent a first H2-TPR process in 10% H2/Ar mixture from 50 to 300°C at a rate of 5°Cmin−1 and held the temperature until no more H2 consumption occurred. Then, the temperature was cooled to 50°C in N2 and the gas was switched to 10% N2O/N2 (40mL/min) for 1h to make the reduced surface Cu atoms oxidized to surface Cu2O:2Cu(s) +N2O→N2 +Cu2O(s). After that, the catalyst was purged with Ar to remove the oxidant and the temperature was cooled to 50°C. The second H2-TPR was carried out from 50 to 300°C and held at 300°C for 1h to reduce surface Cu2O:Cu2O(s) +H2 →2Cu(s) +H2O. Correspondingly, metallic Cu surface area (S cu, m2/g) was calculated as the following equation: (1) S Cu = X × S F × N A N Cu where X (mol/g) is moles of H2 consumption per gram of catalyst in the second H2-TPR process, SF is stoichiometric factor which is taken as 2, N A is Avogadro's constant (6.022×1023/mol), and N Cu is number of surface Cu atoms per unit surface area (1.46×1019/m2). Copper dispersion degree (D Cu, %), defined as the ratio of Cu exposed at the surface to total Cu content, was calculated as the following equation: (2) D Cu = 2 X Y × 100 where Y (mol/g) is moles of H2 consumption per gram of catalyst in the first H2-TPR process. 2.3 Catalytic test The hydrogenation of DMCD was carried out using a stainless-steel fixed-bed tubular reactor with an inner diameter of 12mm. The calcined CuZnAl-LDH sample (3.0g) was loaded into tubular reactor with quartz powders packed in both sides of the catalyst bed with a height of approximately 40mm, and then were reduced in a 10% H2/N2 atmosphere at 300°C for 2h at a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. Before reaction, DMCD (purity >99%) was mixed with methanol solvent to prepare a DMCD/methanol reaction liquid with a mass fraction of 10.0wt.%. Then, the reaction mixture liquid was fed into the reactor by constant-flux pump. Simultaneously, the flow rate of high purity H2 (84,000ml/h) was controlled by gas mass flow meter to achieve a H2/DMCD molar ratio of 406 (mol/mol). During hydrogenation, the total pressure was kept at 8.0MPa, the reaction temperature was kept at 200–240°C, and the room-temperature liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of DMCD was 0.4h–1. Finally, the liquid products were analyzed by an Agilent GC7890A gas chromatograph equipped with flame ionization detector and HP-5 capillary column. In addition, catalysts with different grain diameters were used to check the effect of internal diffusion. It was found that the conversion of DMCD did not vary when the grain diameter of the catalyst was less than 40 meshes. Also, there was no difference in the DMCD conversion under two different catalyst amounts of 2.0g and 3.0g when the applied values of LHSV and H2/DMCD molar ratio kept constant, which indicated that the external mass transfer limitation could be neglected in the present system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural properties The XRD patterns of CuZnAl-LDH precursor present a series of sharp and symmetric characteristic diffractions of hydrotalcite-like materials corresponding to (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) planes of LDH phase (JCPDS no. 37-0630) [32,33] (inset in Fig. 1A). The XRD characterizations of calcined samples at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 1A. After calcination, the layered structure of CuZnAl-LDH has been destroyed completely, due to the removal of interlayer water, the dehydroxylation of the lattices and the decomposition of interlayer carbonate. In the cases of C-400 and C-500, a broad diffraction peak at ca. 36°, which is obviously different from those of simple metal oxides (e.g. CuO, ZnO and Al2O3), is observed, suggestive of the formation of solid Cu–Zn–Al oxide solution (denoted as composite metal oxides). As for C-600, the diffractions associated with the crystalline forms of CuO (JCPDS no. 05-0661) and ZnO (JCPDS no. 36-1451) can be found, besides those of composite metal oxides. When the calcination temperature reaches 700°C, all diffractions related to metal oxides are enhanced, suggestive of the increase in the crystallite sizes of metal oxides, and simultaneously spinel-type phases, such as CuAl2O4 and/or ZnAl2O4, can be formed. However, it is rather difficult to distinguish between these spinels due to their almost identical diffraction positions. In addition, no characteristic diffractions related to Al2O3 phase are observed during the above process, implying that the Al2O3 exists in the amorphous form. As shown in Fig. 1B, the XRD patterns of reduced catalysts clearly present a strong (111) diffraction at 2θ of 43.3° along with two weak (200) and (220) ones at 50.4° and 74.1°, which is characteristic of fcc metallic copper phase (JCPDS no. 01-1241). In addition, with increasing calcination temperature, the diffractions from ZnO and spinel phases can be distinguished more easily. The average crystallite sizes of copper particles calculated by the Scherrer formula according to the (111) diffraction are listed in Table 1 . Notably, the crystallite sizes of copper particles are strongly dependent on the calcination temperature. The crystalline size of Cu0 particles in the R-400 is about 9.4nm, which is slightly larger than that in the R-500 (about 8.8nm). Interestingly, the diffractions of metallic copper in the R-600 become wider and weaker, indicative of the presence of smaller copper particles (7.4nm). However, larger copper particles with the average size of 18.8nm exist in the R-700, due to the presence of the larger bulk CuO particles in the C-700. The textural properties of reduced catalysts are listed in Table 1. Note that R-600 has larger specific surface area of 47m2/g and relatively larger pore volume of 0.38m3/g, compared with other three catalysts. In contrast, the specific surface area of R-700 is the smallest. Usually, the poor specific surface area can result in the aggregation of metal particles [34,35]. The above results further confirm that the high specific surface area is advantageous to the dispersion of copper species in catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the HRTEM images of reduced catalysts. In the cases of R-400 and R-500, metallic copper clusters are dispersed on the support surface and with a little agglomeration (Fig. 2a and b). For R-600, a better dispersion of copper clusters without agglomeration of particles is observed (Fig. 2c and e), which should be mainly attributed to the relatively larger specific surface area preventing the growth and agglomeration of copper particles. As expected, some irregular larger black particles are detected on the R-700 (Fig. 2d), as a result of the sintering of fine copper-containing metal oxide particles and the formation more spinel phases in the C-700. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 2f–i, the Cu, Zn and Al element mapping images of R-600 match with that of the corresponding STEM image, and relatively homogeneous distributions of Cu, Zn and Al atoms are observed. The above result implies that deriving ZnO, Al2O3 and spinel phases as dispersants in reduced catalysts should inhibit the growth of copper nanoparticles [36–39]. 3.2 Redox behaviors H2-TPR characterization was performed to investigate the redox properties of calcined LDHs. As shown in Fig. 3 , the total hydrogen consumption corresponds to the reduction of Cu2+ species to Cu0 and/or Cu+ species. It is found that two kinds of copper species exist in the C-400. The large main peak at ca. 301°C is assigned to the reduction of Cu2+ species in the form of composite metal oxides, while the smaller shoulder at ca. 252°C is ascribed to the reduction of isolated highly dispersed CuO [40]. Compared with C-400, C-500 shows a similar reducible property in spite of a lower reduction temperature. As for C-600, an intensive and symmetrical peak appears at the lower temperature of 192°C, suggesting that the Cu2+ species are reduced more easily, which originates from the presence of highly dispersed copper species [41]. In the case, Cu2+ species in the forms of CuO and Cu-containing spinel can be reduced simultaneously at low temperatures due to their identical highly dispersed nature. In the case of C-700, there is only a broad and asymmetrical H2 consumption peak at ca. 235°C, which is associated with the reduction of larger bulk Cu-containing particles. Thus, the well dispersed copper species existing in CuO and spinel phases, as well as the lower reduction temperature, can be achieved from C-600. On the other hand, the ratios of the amount of H2 consumed to the theoretical amount for complete reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 are calculated to 0.70 for C-400, 0.74 for C-500, 0.84 for C-600 and 0.91 for C-700. The result suggests that with the increasing calcination temperature, the degree of reduction for Cu2+ species in calcined samples is enhanced, and more Cu0 species exist in reduced samples. Correspondingly, the ratios of bulk Cu+/(Cu0 +Cu+) species in reduced samples are estimated to be 0.60 for R-400, 0.52 for R-500, 0.32 for R-600 and 0.20 for R-700. 3.3 Chemical state and surface composition of catalysts The surface/near-surface chemical states of calcined samples were analyzed by XPS measurements (Fig. 4A). In each case, the Cu 2p 3/2 regions show the presence of four peaks in the range of 930–945eV. The binding energy (BE) range found in the literature for the main Cu 2p3/2 peak related to Cu2+ ions of CuO phase is about between 933.0 and 934.0eV [42,43], whereas its shake-up satellite line generally lies between 940 and 945eV. The position of these peaks depends on the chemical composition, the crystalline structure and the near environment of Cu2+ ions of materials [44]. As for C-400 and C-500, the Cu 2p3/2 peak at about 933.8eV is attributed to Cu2+ species present in (composite) metal oxide (CuA 2+), while the peak at 935.6eV may be associated with covalent Cu2+ O bond polarized by Zn2+ and Al3+ ions (CuB 2+) thereby increasing the effective charge of Cu2+ species. And, note that the increasing calcination temperature favors CuB 2+ rather than CuA 2+ cations, due to the formation of more spinel phases in the C-600 and C-700. Reduced samples have been characterized by XPS to obtain more information about the surface Cu oxidation state. As shown in Fig. 4B, in all cases, the Cu 2p3/2 signal at ca. 932.6eV is due to the presence of metallic copper and/or Cu(I) species [45,46]. Further evidence of the copper reduction stems from the absence of XPS signals of Cu2+ at 934–936eV and the shake-up satellite of Cu2+ at ca. 940–945eV. XAES analysis was further carried out to examine the chemical states of surface copper species after reduction. Usually, the modified Auger parameter α′ represents the summation of the kinetic energy (KE) of Cu LMM Auger electron and the BE of Cu 2p 3/2 photoelectron. Correspondingly, the value of α′ can be applied to distinguish between Cu0 with a α′ value of 1851.0eV and Cu+ with the α′ value of 1849.0eV [47]. Obviously, note from Fig. 5 that the broad and asymmetrical Cu LMM spectrum suggests the presence of one more component. The KE at ca. 916.4eV is assigned to Cu+ species and ca. 918.3eV to Cu0 species. Moreover, the surface Cu+/(Cu+ +Cu0) intensity ratio decreases gradually with the calcination temperature (Table 1). The high surface Cu+/(Cu+ +Cu0) ratios (>40%) for R-400 and R-500 signify the hindrance for Cu2+ reduction in calcined samples, probably due to strong interaction between Cu2+ species and ZnO-containing matrix, thus leading in the formation of Cu+ OZn like structure [48]. As for R-600, the content of Cu0 species on the surface is dominant, suggesting that a part of Cu+ OZn structure is destroyed at higher calcination temperature. With the increasing calcination temperature, CuO species weakly interacting with the support can be readily reduced to Cu0 and the surface Cu+/(Cu+ +Cu0) ratio decreases to about 12.1% in the case of R-700. The change in the surface Cu+/(Cu+ +Cu0) ratios in reduced samples is consistent with that in the bulk Cu+/(Cu+ +Cu0) ratios obtained from H2-TPR results. 3.4 Metallic copper surface area and copper dispersion degree The results of metallic copper surface area and copper dispersion measured by H2-N2O titration are shown in Table 1. However, in order to obtain Cu dispersion degree, when using the amount of H2 consumption in the first H2-TPR process and that in the second H2-TPR process to represent the total amount of Cu2+ and that of surface Cu2+ in samples, respectively, incomplete reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ can lead to underestimation of total Cu2+ and surface Cu2+, although the method was used widely to determine Cu dispersion degree of a variety of supported Cu-based catalysts containing Cu+ species in the literature [30,31,49]. As it is difficult to determine the exact amounts of total Cu2+ and surface Cu2+ from the H2-TPR processes, the values of Cu dispersion obtained in the present catalyst system only can be considered as nominal, as also was reported by Esposito et al. [50]. In contrast, metallic copper surface area obtained can actually represent the amount of surface metallic copper and thus the character of copper dispersion. It is seen that the metallic copper surface areas and copper dispersion degrees of reduced samples do not change monotonically with the increasing calcination temperature, well consistent with the change in crystalline size of metallic copper particles determined by XRD patterns. Compared with other reduced samples, R-600 exhibits the largest exposed metallic copper surface area. 3.5 Gas phase hydrogenation of DMCD The catalytic performance of reduced copper-based catalysts was investigated in gas-phase hydrogenation of DMCD. Steady-state product compositions were obtained after about 2h on stream. It is well documented that the catalytic hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM usually goes through a complex multi-step reaction pathway (Scheme 1 ), and that CHDM can be further dehydrated to 4-methyl-cyclohexanemethanol (MCHM). Meanwhile, the accumulation of methyl 4-hydroxymethylcyclohexane carboxylate (MHMCC) intermediate cannot be neglected. As shown in Fig. 6A and Table 2 , the conversion of DMCD increases steadily from 80.1% over R-400 to 99.8% over R-600 under the reaction conditions, and then dropped to 63.6% over R-700. Among catalysts, R-600 shows the highest DMCD conversion with 95.8% selectivity to CHDM; the selectivity to MHMCC remains quite low (<1%). Further, a small part of CHDM can be converted continually into MCHM through hydrogenolysis over R-600 catalyst, due to the presence of highly active metallic copper sites for the dissociation of hydrogen in hydrogenation [51]. Over R-400, R-500 and R-700 catalysts, the selectivity to MHMCC is more than 5%; incomplete hydrogenation product, 4-(hydroxymethyl)-1-cyclohexanecarboxaldehyde (HMCCA), can be detected. Additionally, traditional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and Cu-Cr2O3 catalysts were used here as comparison catalysts. Note from Table 2 that the efficiency of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 is markedly lower than that of R-600, probably owing to inhomogeneous dispersion of active species. Compared with that over R-600, a slightly lower conversion of DMCD is achieved over Cu-Cr2O3. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 6B, when keeping other reaction conditions unchanged, the conversion of DMCD over R-600 increases slightly from 96.7 to 100% with the reaction temperature elevated from 200 to 240°C, and the selectivity to CHDM increases slightly from 94.8 to 95.8% and then drops slightly. Commonly, the dissociation of molecular hydrogen on active metallic copper sites as the rate-determining step is an endothermic reaction, so increasing reaction temperature can increase the rate of hydrogen dissociation. The long-term stability of catalyst is very significant for its practical utilization. Generally, the activity loss for metal-based catalysts can be attributed to the surface transmigration and aggregation of metal nanoparticles. Fig. 7A presents comparisons of the DMCD conversion and CHDM selectivity as a function of time on stream for R-600 and traditional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts. R-600 exhibits high stability for the hydrogenation of DMCD up to 100h and no obvious decrease in either DMCD conversion or CHDM selectivity can be observed. In contrast, obvious deactivation of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 is observed within 24h under identical reaction conditions. In addition, it can be seen from Fig. 7B that compared to that of R-600, the stability of R-400, R-500 and R-700 catalysts decreases at different degrees. The catalytic activity of catalysts begins to decline when the reaction time is prolonged to about 68h for R-400, 80h for R-500 and 52h for R-700, respectively. Therefore, it is concluded that the stability of catalysts increases in the order R-700<R-400<R-500<R-600. In the present catalyst systems, the excellent catalytic stability of R-600 catalyst should be ascribed to the strong metal-support interaction, as well as the high dispersion of copper species on the support, thus stabilizing the active copper species. According to the above XAES analysis results, metallic copper species as the major component exist on the surface of R-600. Moreover, the highest CHDM conversion can be achieved over R-600 catalyst, indicating that Cu0 species should be the effective catalytic centers for the hydrogenation. The quantity of dissociative hydrogen on the active sites directly determines the rate of the reaction. Therefore, larger metallic copper surface area means more dissociated hydrogen. On the other hand, in order to rigorously compare the intrinsic nature of catalytically active copper sites on different catalysts, the DMCD conversion data limited to less than 30% by adjusting the LHSV of DMCD were used to estimate the initial turnover frequency (TOF) according to the moles of DMCD converted by each mole of the surface metallic copper on the catalyst in the initial 1h. As listed in Table 2, it is interesting to note that the TOF value decreases gradually from R-400 to R-500, R-600 and R-700. It indicates that R-400 shows the highest activity among four catalysts, although R-600 possesses the largest metallic copper surface area. The above results suggest that the surface metallic Cu species are not the only important catalytically active sites, and the hydrogenation of DMCD is a structure-sensitive reaction. In the present catalyst system, the promotional effect of Cu+ species on the hydrogenation of DMCD should occur. This is because Cu+ as electrophilic or Lewis acid sites can polarize the CO bond via the lone pair electron on oxygen [49,52], thereby improving the reactivity of the ester group in DMCD. However, compared to those over R-500 and R-600 catalysts, the decreased DMCD conversion over R-400 catalyst is due to its relatively smaller metallic copper surface area, in spite of a larger Cu+/(Cu0 +Cu+) molar ratio on the surface of R-400. As a result, the calcination temperature is an important factor affecting the composition, structure, and chemical states of copper-based catalysts and thus the catalytic properties in the gas-phase DMCD hydrogenation. Base on the above results, a possible mechanism for hydrogenation reaction of DMCD over LDH-derived copper-based catalysts is proposed (Scheme 2 ), where only hydrogenation of one ester group is shown. First, Cu0 on the catalyst surface acting as the active site dissociates adsorbs H2, while Cu+ further polarizes the CO bond in ester group. Subsequently, hydrogenation of CO bond takes place via the surface reaction between the spillover hydrogen species and DMCD reactant, because a great number of works have confirmed the existence of the spillover of dissociatively adsorbed H atoms on Cu0 [53–55]. Finally, DMCD transforms gradually to MHMCC by eliminating a CH3OH molecule and further hydrogenating acyl group. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have demonstrated a highly dispersed, stable and efficient copper-based catalyst derived from CuZnAl-LDH precursor for gas-phase hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM. It was found that the calcination temperature had a significant effect on the composition, structure, chemical states, and catalytic performance of copper-based catalysts. A higher CHDM yield of 95.6% was achieved over R-600 with the larger metallic copper surface area, due to the presence of more highly dispersed active metallic copper species and a reasonable Cu0/Cu+ ratio, which made the catalyst possess a large amount of active Cu0 species to dissociate hydrogen and enough Cu+ species to activate DMCD. This approach of using the CuZnAl-LDH as catalyst precursor to synthesize supported copper-based catalysts may gain some new insights into the hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM process and guidance significance for its further industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Highly dispersed and stable supported copper-based catalysts for gas-phase hydrogenation of dimethyl 1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylate (DMCD) to 1,4-cyclohexane dimethanol (CHDM) were synthesized from a single-source Cu–Zn–Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursor. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2 sorption, H2-N2O titration and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques. The results revealed that calcination temperature for LDH precursors significantly affected the composition, structure, chemical states, and catalytic performance of copper-based catalysts. In the gas-phase selective hydrogenation of DMCD, a high CHDM yield of 95.6% was achieved over copper-based catalyst obtained at calcination temperature of 600°C. Compared with the conventional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and Cr2O3 promoted copper-based catalysts, LDH-derived Cu-based catalysts exhibited higher catalytic performance, which was mainly attributed to the presence of highly dispersed and stable active metallic copper species, as well as a reasonable amount of Cu+ species facilitating the activation of ester groups of reactants.
coredata.dc:title: Gas phase hydrogenation of dimethyl-1,4-cyclohexane dicarboxylate over highly dispersed and stable supported copper-based catalysts
